This is a protective cover case for the new Quanum Elite micro camera / vtx combo.
Scale by 1000, rotate it on it's face and print with supports. Be careful sliding the camera in. Tilt it down slightly and slide it into the back of the case with slight force. Once its in, tilt it upright and it should snap in nice and snug. Remove it the same way.
Be careful and take time removing the supports so you don't snap the supports.
The base is tilted roughly 20 degrees for those who want some speed.

title: Flexible Landing Gear for Quadcopter "Crossfire" Version 2 [deprecated]

description.text:
This is a deprecated version. New version available here:
Flexible Landing Gear for Quadcopter "Crossfire" Version 3

Improved version of my flexible landing gear for MikeyB's quadcopter "Crossfire". After some stress testing (hard landings and scratching on asphalt) I detected that they were too flexible, so I improved the stability. This updated version is more stable while still being flexible enough to reduce hard shocks from uncontrolled landings (especially made by beginners). It's also now 45 degrees instead of 60 degrees relative to the arms. The idea behind the opened and bended shape is to allow flexibility not only for bending the leg but also for pushing it (shrinking in length). This also dampens shocks when landing "diagonally" oriented, which might happen to beginners every now and then... The landing gears are long enough to protect the battery (they stand out normally about 8cm and if bended about 7cm measured from the bottom plate), however if you carry a camera on the bottom you should check and maybe enlarge them as needed. Take about 1 - 1.5cm of flexibility into account when doing so.

title: Quadrifilar Helix Antenna Cross Arms Drill Guide

description.text:
These drill guides were designed in order to create a Quadrifilar Helix Antenna (QFH) using an infinite balun design tuned to 137.5 MHz for the NOAA 19 Satellite as described below:

Original Build Guide:
http://www.qsl.net/yo4tnv/docs/ARRL%20UHF%20Microwave%20Projects%201997.pdf (Page 1-39)

Step by Step instructions:
http://www.rish.kyoto-u.ac.jp/digitalbeacon/information/Building_QFH_Antenna_Guide.pdf

Dimensions of Pipes Used:

Center Column:

2 inch PVC pipe with an outer diameter of 2.4 inches

Leg pipes:

1/2 inch PVC pip with an outter diameter of 0.6 inches

Words of Caution:

This antenna drill guide is only for constructing a QFH antenna tuned to 137.5 MHz. You could potentially get away with anything around the 137 MHz region but it is definitely not suited for wifi or short wave radio. So that being said don't print and hope that your antenna will work using these drill guides.

Design & Test Adventure:

Since I did not have a drill press that was capable of drill through holes I tried many techniques to drill the arm holes at 90 degree angles with no luck. I would either end up with weird offset holes that were out of angle or I would get holes that looked perfect and when I fit the cross arms in the arm holes would look way out of angle. So to fix the problem I looked into 3D Printing some drill guides. After research and some time designing (and redesigning) these guides using tinkerkad I finally settled on this model. Had them printed and used the slotted line to line up with the drill targets I made for easier alignment (added perpendicular lines to step 5 and 6 from the step by step guide for each of the leg holes markings) then marked the holes and presto perfectly aligned 90 degree holes. You can see the final results in the actual antenna that is now mounted outside. The cross arms holes in the main column are what these drill guides are for. Because of my success with this first every 3D Print I have proudly bought a FlashForge Creator Pro 2016 model which has proven the best investment I made since my university education.

Future Changes:

In the future I would like to modify this design to reduce the leg holes to a simple point which you could mark with a tip of a pencil. I believe the current design was a bit clumsy (although it works well) since some users may use different size piping than the one recommended in the step by step guide mentioned above. Another addition would be to add horizontal groves in order to align with the markings that are drawn around the perimeter of the center main column. If time permits I will upload the aforementioned fixes.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

15%

Notes:

This was printed on a makerbot over at Makerthings in Montreal Canada. The print settings I have above seem to be correct and what I remember the clerk telling me he used. In the end this design is easy to print so you can use whichever settings you feel comfortable with.

Post Printing

After you print these drill guides I noticed that not all 2 inch and 1/2 inch pipes are the same so you may have to sand the holes so like that your pipe fits. Other than sanding holes there is nothing else that needs to be done.

author: jwjcullen

description.text:
Double female LEGO plate piece so you can insert the stud side of the lego into both sides. I saw some other parametric SCAD LEGO things on thingiverse but I didn't like the way they made their double female parts. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:615256
Although they have a double female option, it is not designed in the same manner as this one, my way is more efficient being hollow and having a shorter print time while representing a real LEGO piece that I incidently can't find online anywhere. I'll see if I can find the piece in my lego pit though.

I remember seeing this part in maybe a MEGABLOKS set but I haven't seen it anywhere here and I can't seem to find it online either so here it is.

This is a follow up to this non-customizable version I made earlier this week: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1608070

Edit: My plan now is to make more of the specialized lego parts. The ones that're particularly useful but incidentally more rare. I only have 2 or 3 of these double female parts in 40 lbs of legos, but now I have like 15 more of them and am also no longer bound to the 2x2 plate shape.

I plan on making some right angle female/male pieces and other customizable potentially useful pieces.

description.text:
The Raspberry Pi is a creditcard sized computer which you can buy for $25 or $35 (depending which version) Never designed a case before, so perhaps things can be better... ...... v11 Different splitlevel (more simple) on backside
keep a little margin on back split, so that top and bottom always fit
added openlogo option
added pcbholder option
changed support studs a bit
changed dimensions to 85.0 x 56.20 v12 Different component locations/sizes
keep a little margin on component holes
pcbsize to 57.0 x 86.0 (actual it is 56.17 x 85.0)
made casestuds wider and added 2 minor holes for self tapping screws v14 Got a RPI.. so production board measurements... v15 moved the rca and snd a bit to get them more centered
Thanks to lincomatic at Thingiverse
Added option for GPIO side hole in bottom or top
Added showing GPIO pins with component drawing If it fits or doesn't, please let me know.. The bottomholder_frame.stl is a standlone minimal frame for a RPi.
All the other bottom_xxx and top_xxx.stl files can be combined.
If you want something specific just take the openscad file and alter it, or just ask...

// All parts are draw as default just disable the ones you don't want
DRAWfull = 1;
DRAWtop = 1;
DRAWbottom = 1;
DRAWtopinlet = 0;
DRAWbottominlet = 0;
DRAWpcb = 1; GPIOHOLE = 2; // GPIO opening in : 1=bottom 2=top
GPIOsize = 2; // define height of gpiohole If you draw 1 part, it will center, otherwise multiple parts are showed. You can control the case looks by changing :
topframe = false; // if false, underneath values determines how
topinlet = false; // false is outside, otherwise it is with an indent
topholes = true;
topmiddle = true;
toplogo = false;
toplogohole = true; // cut out logo, so you have a view on the pcb
toplogosunken=false; // true or false, no idea if this works on a reprap
bottomframe = false; // if false, underneath values determines how
bottominlet = false;
bottomholes = true;
bottomscrew = false;
bottomfeet = false;
bottomsupport = true; // Added extra support locations for pcb
bottomclick = true;
bottompcb = false; // just a pcb holder without a top Controlling the size of the case can be done by: box_thickness = 2.0; // minimum = 2.0 for RepRap printing Low box (red box in picture):
inside_h = 12.1; // USB goes through deck, 16.5=full height
pcb_h = 5.6; // room for SDslot and a deck Normal box:
inside_h = 16.5;
pcb_h = box_thickness*2+3.5;

OpenSCAD deltoidal hexecontahedron tile with holes for magnets.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deltoidal_hexecontahedron

You'll need to print a total of 60 tiles, and 4 disc magnets per tile (axially magnetized). That's 240 magnets in total. I bought mine on eBay in bulk and used superglue to secure them in the tiles.

See the User Defined Variables section of the OpenSCAD script for the parameters you may want to change (magnet holes and overall size of tile, total 4 parameters). Or just use the pre-built STL with 6mm diameter magnets.

Not familiar with OpenSCAD? It is easy to obtain and use! Download it here: http://www.openscad.org. After installation, open up the OpenSCAD file for this thing and hit F6 to render (or use the menu options up top). File->Export as STL and take it to your slicer!

These are also on github: https://github.com/eshira/polyhedra

Magnet Orientations

Opposite sides have the same polarities facing out.
Adjacent sides have opposite polarities facing out.

For example, you could go around the tile starting at any face and go North - South - North - South. Make sure all tiles have identical magnet alignment!!! A good way to keep track is to make your first tile according to the rules above, and use it as a references for every subsequent tile (test your magnets against it).

description.text:
Do you like to have a camera in your garden for your burglars?

You know:
Most available wireless cameras works not encrypted. Your burglar can drive with his car watching his monitor, near your garden he will have a view inside. So he can find out easily if you are in vacancy, if a dog, where the most weak window to come in.

Some WiFi cameras use the UPnP mechanism of your firewall. So you can watch your garden by any internet connection. Combination of weak default passwords and software bugs also provide full access to burglar mafia networks. Also they can watch your garden if you are in vacancy or if you're sleeping with your girlfriend outside.

A camera will not help you for burglars. When they are coming, they are coming. When you are in vacancy, maybe you don't like to watch your garden day and night. If you have a combination of camera and motion detection, the system will disturb you in the night when a cat or fox is coming in the garden.
And, what's about privacy? Your boss, NSA, Trump's muslims, all are watching you???

Here is the perfect solution for your problems: a fake camera.
Schematic shows a LED flashlight. It flashes permanently, extreme long battery lifetime. Normally I take used weak batteries It runs over months with no extra cost. New battery will run some years. An option in the schematic will make a very fast flashing, you will see a permanent light. This schematic contains a voltage doubler, you can run a (ultrabright!) LED, normally 1.5V with a weak 1.2V battery. Or, you'll take 2 batteries and a blue or white LED. Add a fake cable if you like and the burglar sees a real camera. That's all you need, and it provides full privacy.

Print:
Should be no problem. I have tested in ABS and PLA. In the design, there is a gap of 0.5mm included between lid and case. Different size .STLs. Numbers are the mm in the outline. In .SCAD file it can be selected freenly.

remixed_from.author: clough42
remixed_from.title: Improved Hexagon Cooling Fan Shroud System for MakerFarm Prusa i3v and i3

title: Modified Improved Hexagon Cooling Fan Shroud

description.text:
This is a modified duct for clough42's Improved Hexagon Cooling Fan Shroud system(thing 335613).
It had been awhile since I've cleaned my printer and there were a lot of particles building up on the hot end's heatsink causing a lot of heat to travel upwards and causing frequent jams. I had the extruder torn apart and while looking at it I thought there was too much room on the sides of the heatsink. So I whipped up a modified air duct with a narrow intake that hugs the hexagon heatsink. I don't know if this is going to help as much as just cleaning all the debris off the fins of the heatsink, but I don't think it will hurt anything either.

comments.text: Looks good.  Thanks for sharing.  I have been thinking about doing this for some time, but haven't gotten back to the project.

title: X Carriage for Wanhao Di3 Toranado PGE

description.text:
Pics Uploaded
Project Completed

---- For this you will need ----

13x m3 knurled nuts (i used the 5mm dia. ones but can alter the design for you if yours are smaller)
12x m3x20 cap screws (this includes those for mounting to the extruder)
1x m3x40 cap screw
1x m3x25(maybe 30) cap screw
1x m3x15 cap screw
2x m3 washer
2x m3 nut
3x lm8uu bearings

*cap screws, machine screws, button head, it's all good.

Instructions:

Seperate parts in slicer. Print with all bearing surfaces up. Use supports.

Heat and insert the knurled nuts (9 in the back, 2 in the tensioner, and 2 get attached to one 20mm bolt and inserted through the x carriage for the non adjustable end of the belt holding mechanism).

Insert 40mm screw through side of carriage,with a washer on either side of the wall, then simultaneously screw the two nuts and the tensioner onto the screw with the two nuts closest to the screw head. once they are all on the shaft adjust the two nuts up to the carriage wall so that the screw has minimal play but still turns freely. Then tighten the two nuts against each other. turning the screw should now adjust the tensioner back and forth.

screw m3x15 into the tensioner so that it sticks out enough for the belt to loop around.

Gently press the linear bearings into position ensuring they are home and not on an angle. then screw on the lower bearing cover. (6x m3x20 screws) there is no need for this to be very tight, you don't want to squash your bearings.

attach x axis micro switch with the screws that they were originally attached with (m2x8 at a guess)

Attach extruder with 3x m3x20 screws.

attach top bearing cover with 2x m3x20 screws. the other one clamps the bearing and the cable chain.

Install x carriage onto printer.

attach belt in a similar fashion to the original and tighten with the tensioner.

attach cable chain with m3x25(or 30)

Plug everything in.

comments.text: Sir, you mentioned that you would be willing to resize the m3 knurled nut holes? I have the 4mm outer diameter knurled nuts - could you please resize to accomodate these?
comments.author: gbass01

comments.text: will this work with the latest side mount version?
comments.author: gbass01

comments.text: How much z-height do you have with this extruder installed? Were you able to keep the full 180, or did you lose a bunch?
comments.author: VeeDubb65

comments.text: Hi, I apologise for taking so long to get back to you. I was able to keep the full 180 but with heavy modification by trimming the upper brace with an angle grinder. without modification i would say you could keep 150-160mm, it's hard to tell exactly where the extruder would stop as that part has been physically cut away.
comments.author: VeeDubb65

comments.text: My only question is how do you attach the belt?
comments.author: SirPrintyMcPrinterperson

comments.text: I have added a photo which shows the way that the belt is attached. if you can see, there are two m3 screws that sick out of the back of the carriage which the belt is looped onto in the same way that the original one was. However one comes out of a smaller tensioner. In the photo you can see the tensioner is on a long m3 screw which allows the tensioner to be positioned to tighten the belt. i thought i had a 50mm screw but i only had a 40mm which i used to assemble this carriage which is why the screw doesn't go all the way through.
comments.author: SirPrintyMcPrinterperson

comments.text: Many thanks friend. I do have one question regarding your x carriage and that is can it use IGUS bearings instead?
comments.author: Beevus

comments.text: Yes and no. IGUS bearings require to be pressed into a steel or rigid sheath. If you have the ones that are then assuming they have the same outer dimensions as the lm8uu bearings then yes. If you have the ones that are just a printed part then no, these need to be pressed into a correctly sized rigid cavity for an interference fit, there is lots of information about this on the reprap forums and other places. I designed this with the lm8uu bearings in mind not the IGUS ones.
comments.author: SirPrintyMcPrinterperson

comments.text: Okay thanks for telling me then. I'll design my own Wanhao Tornado carriage for IGUS bearings then (I've been meaning to get around it anways).
comments.author: Beevus

title: E3d-V6 holder and bowden for Migbot 3D

description.text:
Support for the original E3D-V6 for mounting on 3D Migbot.
It attaches to the original X carriage.

The ducts fans are downloadable here -> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1337200

The sensor holder (optional) is for Ø18mm sensors.

The Bowden is based on the original Bowden. You can recover all the parts of it for editing. It is designed to be fixed on the left side at the top (see photos).

Update 24/06/2016
Add a new lateral fan duct for 50mm fan.
Add a new E3D-V6 fan duct for 40mm fan.

Printer:

Migbot 3D

Notes:

Infill: 50% for bowden parts

title: Replacement feet for Dell RT7D50 Keyboard
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Replacement feet for the Dell RT7D50 keyboard. The feet fit over the ridge that runs along the bottom of the keyboard as in the picture (please excuse my blobby glueing!)

The angle is slightly steeper than the original feet, but only slightly. Remix if this angle is too much for you.

There are a few Dell keyboards that look similar to the RT7D50 and these feet may fit them too.

description.text:
This plan was a donation from GrblGru, the developer behind the 3D-simulation for cnc-machines with the same name. The complexity of the puzzle seems low, but taking the pieces it's actually quite hard to solve.

My build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 6.5 mm beech plywood using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute. The other is build with two layers of baltic birch plywood, doubling the size. However the drawing is created for using 8 mm material!

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.
I created to versions of the dxf for laser which is closely nested an uses only single cuts and a version for cnc-machines. The drawing must be scaled to match the material width.

description.text:
This was a project I did with my Computer Science Class this year. I gave my students the assignment to use OpenSCAD to create something to hold their cell phones. I've included some of the STLs and a couple SCAD files as examples of what they made.

One of my students uploaded her model to the Thingiverse. It is Thing: 1311276

Printer:

Polar3D

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Whether raft or supports are needed depend on the particular phone holder being printed. You will also probably need to change the orientation of the part for optimal printing.

This was a project I did with my Computer Science Class this year. We did this the first week of our second semester. By this point my students had spent a lot of time developing skills in C programming. My main goal was to have students use the skills they'd developed in an entirely new context. This helped me see which skills they really had mastered. The First Prompt:
"Use OpenSCAD to create a stand to hold your cell phone. Be sure to accomodate for your case if you have one. You can make it to hold it upright or sideways or even be able to work for both orientations. Really, make something that would work for you." I provided no instruction in the use of OpenSCAD. I merely pointed them to the documentation page on the OpenSCAD website. After printing their designs I had a second prompt: The Second Prompt:
Change your OpenSCAD code to fix any problems you discovered with your design. Additionally you must add variables that would allow someone to easily change your model so that it can work for any cell phone (except maybe Mr. D-F's flip phone). Objectives:
  • Reinvigorate my students in their study of computer science
  • Gauge my students mastery of computer science concepts already "mastered"
  • Provide students with a challenge that was completely new and yet within their ability
    • Audience:
  • This was done with 11th and 12th graders in a Computer Science class
  • This could be done with any students who already have some programming experience
    • Subjects: Include any relevant subjects i.e. science, math, etc.
  • Computer Science
  • Math - This is all about shapes and/or 3-D coordinate space
    • Skills Learned:
  • Students will learn the basics of OpenSCAD
  • Students will learn the basics of Parametric Design
    • Computational Thinking Practices
  • Connecting Computing
  • Creating Computational Artifacts
  • Abstracting
    • NGSS Disciplinary Core Ideas - Engineering, Technology, and Application of Science
  • ETS1.A: Defining and Delimiting an Engineering Problem
  • ETS1.B: Developing Possible Solutions
  • ETS1.C: Optimizing the Design Solution

• Introduce the activity and provide the prompt. Use OpenSCAD to create a stand to hold your cell phone. Be sure to accomodate for your case if you have one. You can make it to hold it upright or sideways or even be able to work for both orientations. Really, make something that would work for you.
  • Explain the basics of printing on your school's machine and show them the machine in operation.
  • Have students create simple sketches of their design ideas complete with measurements.
  • Provide students a link to the documentation page on the OpenSCAD website and set them to work.
  • Print and test designs.
  • Have students share their designs with the rest of the class. Discuss different design ideas.
  • Provide the second prompt. Change your OpenSCAD code to fix any problems you discovered with your design. Additionally you must add variables that would allow someone to easily change your model so that it can work for any cell phone (except maybe Mr. D-F's flip phone).
  • Print and test designs.
    • Duration:
    This took a week of class time.

• Students need some familiarity with computer programming
  • If students have no programming experience then you will need to spend more time working directly with students to build some basic concepts.
  • You should also share with your students some of the limitations of 3D printing. Overhangs and bridging are obvious ones, but you should also talk about size limitations. I had two designs that were incredibly big and wouldn't fit at all.

• Final Design:
    • Does it actually work? How stable is it?
    • If the design used less plastic would it still work and still be aesthetically pleasing?
  • Computer Science Concepts:
    • Which computer science concepts were applied?
    • Were any concepts avoided that would have made the program easier to write or more efficient?
    • Does changing the parameters for the parametric design work or are there bugs/edge cases?

title: Galaxy S4 battery charger / Batterie Ladestation

description.text:
This is a simple, but very nice and easy to make battery charger for the Galaxy S4 battery. You need to buy the Lithium Battery Charging Board with Micro USB plug from ebay for 1€. Mine is from here: http://www.ebay.de/itm/380857012621?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

For the battery pins, I used some strong copper wire, which can spring a bit or like you can see in the first design, a thin and strong metal plate I hat lying around. Then you just bend it with some small tongs like you see in the photo.

I also uploaded the raw files from Designspark Mechanical, so you can remix the design or make some adjustments. You can also change it, to make it fit other batteries.

UPDATE

Now with spring loaded pins in the overall refined and tweaked design (v7). You can get the pins from here:

http://www.ebay.de/itm/191832709234?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

To put the pins inside, you have to pause the print one layer before the top is closed and insert them carefully. I suggest to move the extruderhead away from the print as long as it is paused, otherwise it can melt. Then just resume the print and the pins will be inside the plastic.

title: MakerFarm Prusa i3 Magma cooling system remix

description.text:
This is a remix of the original cooling system by thiagokunz, which is a must-have for anyone with the Prusa i3 from MakerFarm with the Magma hot end. The differences here from the original:
  • Allowed slightly more fit tolerance between pieces
  • Added retainer clip for wedge (back) piece
  • Added bolt through-holes for easier removal
  • Added the new fan cover as-is with a 90 degree rotation for printing
    • The main feature is the bolt through-holes, which allow you to remove the entire hot end with the cooling system attached (after removing the bolts holding the extruder in place). This will definitely slightly reduce the airflow but should keep to the original design's intention of directing airflow away from the nozzle. The cooling fan for the all-metal Magma hot end is a must, but having air blow on it makes it much harder to reach temperature and interferes with the deposition of material. Use this if you have a need for frequent changing of your extruder head (e.g. if you are swapping it for a CNC router or laser cutter head). Changes:
    v14 (7 Oct 2013) - closed small gap in bolt hole shoulders on main duct shroud
    10 Oct 2013 - Added fan cover (verbatim by thiagokunz, just rotated)

All three stl files can be printed on a 6" bed.  
Use a fine resolution (0.2mm layer height or less) for best results. Infill shouldn't matter much but can be slightly denser than normal.  
The main tray-shaped piece goes under the aluminum cooling block on the hot end. If you have accumulated a large blob of plastic due to leakage, this may prevent inserting it and you will need to heat up your hot end then remove it.  
The wedge piece fits under the small guide clips and should stay in place while putting the extruder assembly back in place. The bolts should go through the bolt pockets. After securing the extruder you can mount the fan to the fan guide. The original M3 bolts won't be long enough - you can use #4-32 1.5" machine screws (available at Lowe's or Home Depot in the US). The fan and fan guide should mount to the extruder holes and you should feel air coming up from the small holes on the front.

comments.text: I dont know how or if this improves airflow, but it does wonders for protecting my fingers and the blades of my fan. Ive gone through 3 fans from carelessness with my fingers! Note: I am useing only the exterior bubble stl.

comments.text: I have it set up to blow on the extruder - that's the original configuration and seems to make sense so I've stuck with it. With this setup it could go either way but I haven't tried it yet. Without ducting only blowing would work.
comments.author: Drexz

comments.text: Hi, why not print whitout the fan? i'm doing it (ABS) and havent had a single jam  :)
comments.author: ogelybogely

comments.text: With ABS it may be possible to avoid jamming. Going to smaller layer heights (0.1mm) and printing with PETT (T-glase) is trickier. The likelihood of jamming may be less if the diameter of your 3mm filament is less (it's usually less than 3mm, how much less may vary). For me, getting my Magma to print without jamming has required getting the right settings, and most definitely printing without the fan (which I haven't tried much, but enough to convince me it's needed) has greatly increased my jamming. The most common jam is the hobbed bolt starts eating a crescent into the filament and I have to back everything out, clean out the hobbed bolt, and re-feed the filament.
comments.author: ogelybogely

comments.text: My understanding of the Magma's PLA issues are that the heat creeps up the PLA itself... and that cladding the stainless tube in foil/keratherm etc so it contacts the sink all the way up should help. I don't have any PLA yet to try it...
comments.author: papergeek

comments.text: That's also my understanding - much of the swelling is caused by heat travelling up the filament itself. The PLA conducts heat, and even more so when it has absorbed moisture (unlike ABS, PLA is hygroscopic). I'm setting up a container with reusable silica gel bags to keep my PLA in and will give it a try in another week or so.
comments.author: derwhalfisch

comments.author: Drexz

comments.text: I should probably also update the build instructions for someone putting this together for a new kit. You'll need longer screws to mount the whole thing to the extruder. The kit from MakerFarm comes with (I think) M4x16mm socket-head screws for this purpose. You will need something longer, at least 25-50mm (1 to 2 inches, I need to check the size I used). In the US you can get metric sizes in longer screw lengths from your local industrial supply house or get #4-40 machine screws from Lowe's or Home Depot (Lowe's may have a slightly better variety of the #4 pan head machine screws in little plastic bags). #4 machine screws fit quite well in the holes on the extruder base (snug without deforming anything).
comments.author: Drexz

description.text:
A shield/box for a DS18B20 style waterproof temperature sensor with a body measuring 50mm long and 6mm thick.
It provides a mounting for the sensor, holds it off the surface to minimise transfer of heat and provides good airflow while completely covering the sensor body, preventing accidental touches that effect readings.
It also should still provide fairly accurate results if something is against it, partly covering the sensor as it helps maintain an air gap.

Enclosure final size: 80mm long, 22mm wide, 10mm high.
4mm screw holes are provided or you could use double-sided tape.
Lid can be glued on or depending on your printer might stay in place on it's own, but this is not recommended. Sensor should stay in from friction, if loose, a drop of hot glue, blu-tack or similar will fix this.
For better finish, try printing the top 'up the right way'. Supports will be required in this case however. To make the sensor cover less visible, paint the printed part it match the surface and maybe the sensor cable.

author: StephenMott

description.text:
A4 sized (297 x 210mm) work area mini vacuum table for your CNC machine.

Great for making PCBs or any other small work.

Runs from a standard vacuum cleaner and sucks pretty hard! I am using a Vax bagless model - the hose fits into the 'Vac adaptor' and is retained by the 'Vac retainer' after removing the handle / wand attachment. I included 3 holes to put small screws or rivets into the retainer but in the end it just pressed together snugly.

The base is made from 32mm MDF and the top from 6-8mm Acrylic.

After cutting the channels etc in base (see DXF layer names for cutting depths) coat the inside with varnish to seal it before assembly. Use a bead of silicone around the vac adaptor and under the bed, as seen in the photo.

Use self tappers or M4 machine screws to attach the bed to the base.

The mounting points are set at 160mm spacing to suit my T-slot table. Adjust as needed.

Ideally, lightly skim the bed after mounting.

description.text:
the pencil holder will teach the everyday student to be organized and lead on with an organized life to be successful in all they do.
One minor change to your everyday life could be the call in whether you are successful or a failure. during this project I learned everyone cannot be successful, because everyone cannot be accessible to this type of technology. before this project you need to know what you are capable off because a simple student may not be up for this part. Make sure that you have some skills with fillets before starting on a project like this.
Hours of thinking and thinking of what I thought I was capable of, all ending in this final little but meaningful project.

When I was a kid I had a funny toy I've never seen again. It has been around my head for ages and now is the time to give it a chance and make it for my nephew. It had a sucker on its bottom and a spring attached to the sucker. When you stick the sucker on a table it holds the spring some time, but in the end after some seconds the sucker unsticks and the spring make the whole thing jump!! It was very funny but, what if you could make jump anything you want? I designed this box that holds inside a sucker and a methacrylate disc (to allow the sucker to stick well. You can use any smooth plastic surface 3mm height / 34mm radius you have around or give a try to your printer to print the disc and keeping the mirror-like face upwards, tough not recommended. Don't use crystal) that achieves the same effect but with an upper compartment where you can put the thing you want to be thrown away. Just press down the compartment to make the sucker stick and wait a bit for it to be thrown away... You can use it as a funny joke where people put something that in the end are going to be flying away whenever it wants. When you don't need anymore a thing, let the magic box throw it away... Or simply use it like a vase without pressing the sucker down, altough I know you are going to press it down a lot of times heheh.

Use some m3 screws and nuts and 3x soft springs to mount it. Easy mount and lots of fun for you and your unaware friends...

HINTS: Don't put inside candy or other food or you will be collecting it from the soil. Don't put inside water or other liquids or you will be taking a shower. Don't make jokes to your pets, or kids as it can thow hard objects to the eyes. Choose mild strength springs. Don't put your car keys or fragile objects inside for evident reasons hahah. BTW it is not a bad idea to fill it with rice in a wedding...

UPDATE (10-JUN-2016):Minor changes in the top part to allow for more compatibility with more suckers and springs. Touching buldplate support is now required for printing this part.

UPDATE (07-JUN-2016): Minor changes in the down part to hide the M3 nuts and make them internal. Also removed some useless material. Sources and STLs updated, pics will be updated when I have the time.

title: Mostly Printed CNC ACME Nut Bracket

description.text:
DO NOT USE!

Tested, and failed. the 5/16" SS rod provided almost no backlash, where this allows the Z axis to "float" about 0.25mm when cutting fast, leaving a rough surface.

Might work well for a 3d printer or laser cutter build; but any sort of spindle will jump.

NOT TESTED! Still waiting for my ACME Nut

This is designed to fit the C Center carriage for the MPCNC, to replace the threaded rod and coupling nut with an acme screw.

The ACME Nut from ebay should slide in, but it will be a tight fit. Recommend (carefully) heating the acme nut to ~230C, and seating it in by re-flowing the ABS. Less play = less backlash. Fit must be very snug. This is the soul of your machine!

Hardware:
4x M3x20 Panhead bolts
4x M3 Locknuts

Again, this has not been tested yet, just a rough draft.

Printer:

CTC Bizer MK8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

55%

Because the nut holes on the bottom are bridged, you will have to clean the bottoms of the holes. Personally, I use an M3 nut wedged on a soldering iron set to 230C, push it into the holes slowly, and re-flow the poorly bridged material, to make a nice clean surface.
Designed with OpenSCAD; by importing the existing part, and filling the holes with cylinders to confirm center. Source file included.

comments.text: I'm not sure about the 3d printer style nuts if that is what this fits, you will for sure need some sort of anti backlash spring and those brass nuts might wear extremely fast with a heavy spindle on there.
comments.author: Allted

title: DJI Inspire 1 Style middle frame landing gear (NOT COMPATIBLE WITH ORIGINAL)

description.text:
PLEASE DO NOT PRINT
THIS IS A PROJECT STILL IN PROGRESS

This part holds the landing gear mechanism for the legs of the inspire 1 and is also the middle frame structure of the drone.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

80

This was one of the toughest part to make, because not only did I have to guest sizes and forms, I also could not get a clear view of any mounting position other than the 4 side mounts shown on some pictures and videos found online. I also had to create the battery holder structure as to get a clearer view of the real width of that piece.

For this part I could have done it in 2 pieces, but I decided to break it apart even more just because I wanted to be able to change printing directions to obtain the best rigidity for the part.

I adapted the part for any standard servo I could find on the net. The choice will be up to you. The top part of the structure will be modified to accommodate even dc motors for those of wish to go down another road.

You will be able to see that no endstop placeholder has been designed as this will no longer be necessary(explanation coming up later on).
The leadscrew and anti backlash nut is a 6mm one found everywhere on the net for around 10$

The bearing slot has also been modified to host many types of bearings

title: Simblee Irresistiblee
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Apologies to Robert Palmer, but this project is "Simblee Irreistiblee." Build your own app that will connect the Internet with any of your things--using Simblee.

RF Digital Corporation has created a small, fingernail-sized chip that enables bi-directional communication between any project and a smart device (NOTE: at the time of this project, May 2016, only iOS devices are supported--Android support is in the works). Remarkably, you build the smart device App INSIDE the chip's firmware. This chip is called Simblee.

Simblee (RF Digital RFD77101) is a unique chip sandwich of a Bluetooth "smart" radio transceiver and an ARM Cortex M0 microcontroller. Even though the Bluetooth portion of this combination is able to belt out comm links via current-sipping Bluetooth low energy (BLE) protocols, the real "secret sauce" of the sandwich is the ability to program this beast with the Arduino Integrated Development Environment (IDE).

The Build

Let's use Simblee for something that's practical for a lot of people--a remote weather station. How many times do you check the weather report with your smart device each morning? More times than not, this compulsive addiction to weather data reaches a peak right before you go out the door in the morning. Is it hot? Do I need a jacket? Should I bring a bottle of water? These are the types of questions that you need answered before leaving your house. Simblee Irreistiblee is able to provide you with five quick weather data points that will help address these questions over a sweet BLE connection:

  • Temperature
  • Humidity
  • The temperature of the Simblee chip (this is just a sanity check for monitoring your project's health)
  • Heat Index (this data point is not available with temperatures less than 79F)
  • Heat Index Effect Level (only applicable on days with a heat index)

The complete building instructions along with Arduino IDE code are available on Hackster.IO at:

https://www.hackster.io/user2657672/simblee-irresistiblee-9b687d

LulzBot

No

Notes:

Be sure to "gently" enlarge the fastener holes in the caps prior to attaching the screws--this will prevent the plastic from cracking.

I set out tryign to make a pin hole camera on the laser with craft wood becuase I loved the feel and aperance of it rather than some plastic. It gave it a much more "analog" and natural feel.
I soon incoutered many problems with fitment that would allow light to leak through the body of the camera so i decided to change mediums and will be design another camera to be printed on a MakerBot. This is what i came up with so far.
Camera was cut on an Epilog Mini 40watt laser using 3mm craft plywood.

author: lilwitch

title: Customizable cd slot holder for phone & tablet - in Ford Fiesta & Ford Ecosport

description.text:
Customisable holder for tablet & phone, by putting into CD slot of Ford Fiesta 2008-2016 or Ford Ecosport 2013-2016.

UPDATE on 26th January 2017: I added 2 holes in the base, so that you can insert metal rod inside for reinforcement if needed (especially for car parking under the Sun, plastic can be weakened). I also add base cutting mode, so that you can print 2 halves of the base (one normal half and one mirrored half).

This thing has 3 parts: 1 base and 2 ends (2 ends are identical). Select "Base" or "End" to generate the STL file for the base part or the end part. After printing, plug the ends on the base, so that your tablet or phone can fit into this thing. Then put it into the CD slot.

Both the base and the end can be customised. You can download the pre-defined base and end STL files. For olde version, there is one pre-defined base, and 3 types of pre-defined ends, all can be plugged on the pre-defined base. One pre-defined end is for device thickness of 8mm (called EndT8.stl), the other is for device thickness 9mm (EndT9.stl), and one other is for device thickness 10mm (EndT10.stl). For version from 26th January 2017, there is two pre-defined halves of a base - so you will need to print two of them - and 4 types of predefined ends of similar naming convention.

If you customise the base and the end, to suit your device, be sure to use the same values of BaseWidth, BaseThickness, BaseHeight for both the base and the end, so that they can be plugged into each other. If you still find problem fitting the ends to the base, change the Tolerance. For example, if the fitting is too tight, then increase Tolerance a bit. If the fitting is too lose, reduce the Tolerance a bit. Tolerance can take negative value.

If the base is too high for your device, and covers some viewable screen area, there are 2 ways to overcome: reducing the BaseHeight or increasing the EndSpacer. A third way is not changing any parameter, but adding an external spacer from your own disposal, such as a rubber/cloth inner cover inside the base. Reducing BaseHeight can also unblock view to the car information screen (especially when using this thing with small tablet or phone). Set EndSpacer to zero if you do not want to have any spacer.

This thing can be easily pulled out from the CD slot if needed.

WARNING: when you put this thing into the CD slot, if there is a CD inside, you can still play the CD, the thing will not tough the CD, however, DO NOT eject the CD (ejected CD will be jammed into this thing).

If the base exceeds the height of your printer, you can cut it into 2 halves, to print them separately, and assemble them as shown in one of the photographs. I prefer a printer with printing height 30cm or more (probably a delta one) to print the base in one piece (for large tablet, such as 9.7 inch IPad). New version has already a mode for cutting the base into two symmetric halves. Use BaseCut as Yes, then use BaseMirror as Yes for generating the mirrored half and BaseMirror as No for generating the normal half.

Car interior, under the Sun, could be very hot, so it is better to use material that can withstand high temperature. ABS is more preferable than PLA. In the new version, you can insert metal rods inside base hole for reinforcement, as shown in the last photograph. Specify the BaseHoleRadius to suit the size of your metal rods.

Printer:

Delta type

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer

Infill:

20%

Notes:

ABS is better than PLA

Build a tiny portable FPV (First-person view) monitor! Great to use as a spectator display at an event or attach to your controller as a backup to goggles. It's rechargeable and has access to the band, channel and brightness controls.

Read the full guide on: https://learn.adafruit.com/fpv-mini-ground-station/overview

The 2.5" tft display is powered by a 500mAh lipo battery and a powerboost 1000c. The Eachine ER32 VRX AV receiver has 32 channels with frequencies from 5645-5945MHz. Small and low cost with a wide voltage input, it connects to the Powerboost 1000c.

You can edit the files here: http://a360.co/1RVqtpu
